column2: PROFESSORS H. AND T. OFFER THEIR SERVICES--CAPTAINS B. ALSO ARE ENLISTED--SLAVE-TRADER GRASPING TIGHTLY HIS PREY, BUT SHE IS RESCUED--LONG CONFLICT, BUT GREAT TRIUMPH--ARRIVAL ON THANKSGIVING DAY, NOV. 25, 1855.
column3: PROFESSORS h AND t OFFER THEIR SERVICES-CAPTAINS b ALSO ARE ENLISTED-SLAVE TRADER GRASPING TIGHTLY HIS PREY, BUT SHE IS RESCUED-LONG CONFLICT, BUT GREAT TRIUMPH-ARRIVAL ON THANKSGIVING DAY, november twenty fifth eighteen fifty five.

column2: It was the business of the Vigilance Committee, as it was clearly understood by the friends of the Slave, to assist all needy fugitives, who might in any way manage to reach Philadelphia, but, for various reasons, not to send agents South to incite slaves to run away, or to assist them in so doing.
column3: It was the business of the Vigilance Committee, as it was clearly understood by the friends of the Slave, to assist all needy fugitives, who might in any way manage to reach Philadelphia, but, for various reasons, not to send agents South to incite slaves to run away, or to assist them in so doing.

column2: Sometimes, however, this rule could not altogether be conformed to.
column3: Sometimes, however, this rule could not altogether be conformed to.

column2: Cases, in some instances, would appeal so loudly and forcibly to humanity, civilization, and Christianity, that it would really seem as if the very stones would cry out, unless something was done.
column3: Cases, in some instances, would appeal so loudly and forcibly to humanity, civilization, and Christianity, that it would really seem as if the very stones would cry out, unless something was done.

column2: As an illustration of this point, the story of the young girl, which is now to be related, will afford the most striking proof.
column3: As an illustration of this point, the story of the young girl, which is now to be related, will afford the most striking proof.

column2: At the same time it may be seen how much anxiety, care, hazard, delay and material aid, were required in order to effect the deliverance of some who were in close places, and difficult of access.
column3: At the same time it may be seen how much anxiety, care, hazard, delay and material aid, were required in order to effect the deliverance of some who were in close places, and difficult of access.

column2: It will be necessary to present a considerable amount of correspondence in this case, to bring to light the hidden mysteries of this narrative.
column3: It will be necessary to present a considerable amount of correspondence in this case, to bring to light the hidden mysteries of this narrative.

column2: The first letter, in explanation, is the following:
column3: The first letter, in explanation, is the following:

column2: LETTER FROM J. BIGELOW, ESQ.
column3: LETTER FROM j BIGELOW, e s q.

column2: WASHINGTON, D.C., June 27, 1854.
column3: WASHINGTON, d c, june twenty seventh eighteen fifty four.

column2: MR.
column3: mr

column2: WM.
column3: w m.

column2: STILL--_Dear Sir_:--I have to thank you for the prompt answer you had the kindness to give to my note of 22d inst. Having found a correspondence so quick and easy, and withal so very flattering, I address you again more fully.
column3: STILL-underscore Dear Sir underscore:--I have to thank you for the prompt answer you had the kindness to give to my note of twenty two d inst. Having found a correspondence so quick and easy, and withal so very flattering, I address you again more fully.

column2: The liberal appropriation for _transportation_ has been made chiefly on account of a female child of ten or eleven years old, for whose purchase I have been authorized to offer $700 (refused), and for whose sister I have paid $1,600, and some $1,000 for their mother, &c.
column3: The liberal appropriation for underscore transportation underscore has been made chiefly on account of a female child of ten or eleven years old, for whose purchase I have been authorized to offer seven hundred dollars (refused), and for whose sister I have paid one thousand six hundred dollars, and some one thousand dollars for their mother, and c.

column2: This child sleeps in the same apartment with its master and mistress, which adds to the difficulty of removal.
column3: This child sleeps in the same apartment with its master and mistress, which adds to the difficulty of removal.

column2: She is some ten or twelve miles from the city, so that really the chief hazard will be in bringing her safely to town, and in secreting her until a few days of _storm_ shall have abated.
column3: She is some ten or twelve miles from the city, so that really the chief hazard will be in bringing her safely to town, and in secreting her until a few days of underscore storm underscore shall have abated.

column2: All this, I think, is now provided for with entire safety.
column3: All this, I think, is now provided for with entire safety.

column2: The child has two cousins in the immediate vicinity; a young man of some twenty-two years of age, and his sister, of perhaps seventeen--_both Slaves_, but bright and clear-headed as anybody.
column3: The child has two cousins in the immediate vicinity; a young man of some twenty two years of age, and his sister, of perhaps seventeen-underscore both Slaves underscore, but bright and clear headed as anybody.

column2: The young man I have seen often--the services of _both_ seem indispensable to the main object suggested; but having once rendered the service, they cannot, and ought not return to Slavery.
column3: The young man I have seen often-the services of underscore both underscore seem indispensable to the main object suggested; but having once rendered the service, they cannot, and ought not return to Slavery.

column2: They look for _freedom_ as the reward of what they shall now do.
column3: They look for underscore freedom underscore as the reward of what they shall now do.

column2: Out of the $300, cheerfully offered for the whole enterprise, I must pay some reasonable sum for transportation to the city and sustenance while here.
column3: Out of the three hundred dollars, cheerfully offered for the whole enterprise, I must pay some reasonable sum for transportation to the city and sustenance while here.

column2: It cannot be much; for the balance, I shall give a draft, which will be _promptly paid_ on their arrival in New York.
column3: It cannot be much; for the balance, I shall give a draft, which will be underscore promptly paid underscore on their arrival in New York.

column2: If I have been understood to offer the whole $300, _it shall be paid_, though I have meant as above stated.
column3: If I have been understood to offer the whole three hundred dollars, underscore it shall be paid underscore, though I have meant as above stated.

column2: Among the various ways that have been suggested, has been that of taking _all of them_ into the cars here; that, I think, will be found impracticable.
column3: Among the various ways that have been suggested, has been that of taking underscore all of them underscore into the cars here; that, I think, will be found impracticable.

column2: I find so much vigilance at the depot, that I would not deem it safe, though, in any kind of carriage they might leave in safety at any time.
column3: I find so much vigilance at the depot, that I would not deem it safe, though, in any kind of carriage they might leave in safety at any time.

column2: All the rest I leave to the experience and sagacity of the gentleman who maps out the enterprise.
column3: All the rest I leave to the experience and sagacity of the gentleman who maps out the enterprise.

column2: Now I will thank you to reply to this and let me know that it reaches you in safety, and is not put in a careless place, whereby I may be endangered; and state also, whether all my propositions are understood and acceptable, and whether, (pretty quickly after I shall inform you that _all things are ready_), the gentleman will make his appearance?
column3: Now I will thank you to reply to this and let me know that it reaches you in safety, and is not put in a careless place, whereby I may be endangered; and state also, whether all my propositions are understood and acceptable, and whether, (pretty quickly after I shall inform you that underscore all things are ready underscore), the gentleman will make his appearance?

column2: I live alone.
column3: I live alone.

column2: My office and bed-room, &c., are at the corner of E. and 7th streets, opposite the east end of the General Post Office, where any one may call upon me.
column3: My office and bed room, and c., are at the corner of e and seventh streets, opposite the east end of the General Post Office, where any one may call upon me.

column2: It would, of course, be imprudent, that this letter, or any other _written_ particulars, be in his pockets for fear of accident.
column3: It would, of course, be imprudent, that this letter, or any other underscore written underscore particulars, be in his pockets for fear of accident.

column2: Yours very respectfully,
column3: Yours very respectfully,

column2: J. BIGELOW.
column3: J. BIGELOW.

column2: While this letter clearly brought to light the situation of things, its author, however, had scarcely begun to conceive of the numberless difficulties which stood in the way of success before the work could be accomplished.
column3: While this letter clearly brought to light the situation of things, its author, however, had scarcely begun to conceive of the numberless difficulties which stood in the way of success before the work could be accomplished.

column2: The information which Mr. Bigelow's letter contained of the painful situation of this young girl was submitted to different parties who could be trusted, with a view of finding a person who might possess sufficient courage to undertake to bring her away.
column3: The information which mr Bigelow's letter contained of the painful situation of this young girl was submitted to different parties who could be trusted, with a view of finding a person who might possess sufficient courage to undertake to bring her away.

column2: Amongst those consulted were two or three captains who had on former occasions done good service in the cause.
column3: Amongst those consulted were two or three captains who had on former occasions done good service in the cause.

column2: One of these captains was known in Underground Rail-Road circles as the "powder boy."[A] He was willing to undertake the work, and immediately concluded to make a visit to Washington, to see how the "land lay." Accordingly in company with another Underground Rail Road captain, he reported himself one day to Mr. Bigelow with as much assurance as if he were on an errand for an office under the government.
column3: One of these captains was known in Underground Rail Road circles as the "powder boy."[A] He was willing to undertake the work, and immediately concluded to make a visit to Washington, to see how the "land lay." Accordingly in company with another Underground Rail Road captain, he reported himself one day to mr Bigelow with as much assurance as if he were on an errand for an office under the government.

column2: The impression made on Mr. Bigelow's mind may be seen from the following letter; it may also be seen that he was fully alive to the necessity of precautionary measures.
column3: The impression made on mr Bigelow's mind may be seen from the following letter; it may also be seen that he was fully alive to the necessity of precautionary measures.

column2: [Footnote A: He had been engaged at different times in carrying powder in his boat from a powder magazine, and from this circumstance, was familiarly called the "Powder Boy."]
column3: [Footnote A: He had been engaged at different times in carrying powder in his boat from a powder magazine, and from this circumstance, was familiarly called the "Powder Boy."]

column2: SECOND LETTER FROM LAWYER BIGELOW.
column3: SECOND LETTER FROM LAWYER BIGELOW.

column2: WASHINGTON, D.C., September 9th, 1855.
column3: WASHINGTON, d c, september ninth eighteen fifty five.

column2: MR.
column3: mr

column2: WM.
column3: w m.

column2: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I strongly hope the little matter of business so long pending and about which I have written you so many times, will take a move now.
column3: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I strongly hope the little matter of business so long pending and about which I have written you so many times, will take a move now.

column2: I have the promise that the merchandize shall be delivered in this city to-night.
column3: I have the promise that the merchandize shall be delivered in this city to night.

column2: Like so many other promises, this also may prove a failure, though I have reason to believe that it will not.
column3: Like so many other promises, this also may prove a failure, though I have reason to believe that it will not.

column2: I shall, however, know before I mail this note.
column3: I shall, however, know before I mail this note.

column2: In case the goods arrive here I shall hope to see your long-talked of "Professional gentleman" in Washington, as soon as possible.
column3: In case the goods arrive here I shall hope to see your long talked of "Professional gentleman" in Washington, as soon as possible.

column2: He will find me by the enclosed card, which shall be a satisfactory introduction for him.
column3: He will find me by the enclosed card, which shall be a satisfactory introduction for him.

column2: You have never given me his name, nor am I anxious to know it.
column3: You have never given me his name, nor am I anxious to know it.

column2: But on a pleasant visit made last fall to friend Wm.
column3: But on a pleasant visit made last fall to friend w m.

column2: Wright, in Adams Co., I suppose I accidentally learned it to be a certain Dr. H----.
column3: Wright, in Adams Co., I suppose I accidentally learned it to be a certain dr H----.

column2: Well, let him come.
column3: Well, let him come.

column2: I had an interesting call a week ago from two gentlemen, masters of vessels, and brothers, one of whom, I understand, you know as the "powder boy." I had a little light freight for them; but not finding enough other freight to ballast their craft, they went down the river looking for wheat, and promising to return soon. I hope to see them often.
column3: I had an interesting call a week ago from two gentlemen, masters of vessels, and brothers, one of whom, I understand, you know as the "powder boy." I had a little light freight for them; but not finding enough other freight to ballast their craft, they went down the river looking for wheat, and promising to return soon. I hope to see them often.

column2: I hope this may find you returned from your northern trip,[A] as your time proposed was out two or three days ago.
column3: I hope this may find you returned from your northern trip,[A] as your time proposed was out two or three days ago.

column2: [Footnote A: Mr. Bigelow's correspondent had been on a visit to the fugitives to Canada.]
column3: [Footnote A: mr Bigelow's correspondent had been on a visit to the fugitives to Canada.]

column2: I hope if the whole particulars of Jane Johnson's case[B] are printed, you will send me the copy as proposed.
column3: I hope if the whole particulars of Jane Johnson's case[B] are printed, you will send me the copy as proposed.

column2: [Footnote B: Jane Johnson of the Passmore Williamson Slave Case.]
column3: [Footnote B: Jane Johnson of the Passmore Williamson Slave Case.]

column2: I forwarded some of her things to Boston a few days ago, and had I known its importance in court, I could have sent you one or two witnesses who would prove that her freedom was intended by her before she left Washington, and that a man was _engaged_ here to go on to Philadelphia the same day with her to give notice there of her case, though I think he failed to do so.
column3: I forwarded some of her things to Boston a few days ago, and had I known its importance in court, I could have sent you one or two witnesses who would prove that her freedom was intended by her before she left Washington, and that a man was underscore engaged underscore here to go on to Philadelphia the same day with her to give notice there of her case, though I think he failed to do so.

column2: It was beyond all question her purpose, _before leaving Washington and provable too_, that if Wheeler should make her a free woman by taking her to a free state "_to use it rather_."
column3: It was beyond all question her purpose, underscore before leaving Washington and provable too underscore, that if Wheeler should make her a free woman by taking her to a free state "underscore to use it rather underscore."

column2: Tuesday, 11th September.
column3: tuesday the eleventh of september.

column2: The attempt was made on Sunday to forward the merchandize, but failed through no fault of any of the parties that I now know of.
column3: The attempt was made on Sunday to forward the merchandize, but failed through no fault of any of the parties that I now know of.

column2: It will be repeated soon, and you shall know the result.
column3: It will be repeated soon, and you shall know the result.

column2: Whorra for Judge Kane. I feel so indignant at the man, that it is not easy to write the foregoing sentence, and yet who is helping our cause like Kane and Douglas, not forgetting Stringfellow.
column3: Whorra for Judge Kane. I feel so indignant at the man, that it is not easy to write the foregoing sentence, and yet who is helping our cause like Kane and Douglas, not forgetting Stringfellow.

column2: I hope soon to know that this reaches you in safety.
column3: I hope soon to know that this reaches you in safety.

column2: It often happens that light freight would be offered to Captain B., but the owners cannot by possibility _advance_ the amount of freight.
column3: It often happens that light freight would be offered to Captain b, but the owners cannot by possibility underscore advance underscore the amount of freight.

column2: I wish it were possible in some such extreme cases, that after advancing _all they have_, some public fund should be found to pay the balance or at least lend it.
column3: I wish it were possible in some such extreme cases, that after advancing underscore all they have underscore, some public fund should be found to pay the balance or at least lend it.

column2: [I wish here to caution you against the supposition that I would do any act, or say a word towards helping servants to escape. Although I hate slavery so much, I keep my hands clear of any such wicked or illegal act.]
column3: [I wish here to caution you against the supposition that I would do any act, or say a word towards helping servants to escape. Although I hate slavery so much, I keep my hands clear of any such wicked or illegal act.]

column2: Yours, very truly,
column3: Yours, very truly,

column2: J.B.
column3: j b

column2: Will you recollect, hereafter, that in any of my future letters, in which I may use [] whatever words may be within the brackets are intended to have no signification whatever to you, only to blind the eyes of the uninitiated.
column3: Will you recollect, hereafter, that in any of my future letters, in which I may use [] whatever words may be within the brackets are intended to have no signification whatever to you, only to blind the eyes of the uninitiated.

column2: You will find an example at the close of my letter.
column3: You will find an example at the close of my letter.

column2: Up to this time the chances seemed favorable of procuring the ready services of either of the above mentioned captains who visited Lawyer Bigelow for the removal of the merchandize to Philadelphia, providing the shipping master could have it in readiness to suit their convenience.
column3: Up to this time the chances seemed favorable of procuring the ready services of either of the above mentioned captains who visited Lawyer Bigelow for the removal of the merchandize to Philadelphia, providing the shipping master could have it in readiness to suit their convenience.

column2: But as these captains had a number of engagements at Richmond, Petersburg, &c., it was not deemed altogether safe to rely upon either of them, consequently in order to be prepared in case of an emergency, the matter was laid before two professional gentlemen who were each occupying chairs in one of the medical colleges of Philadelphia.
column3: But as these captains had a number of engagements at Richmond, Petersburg, and c., it was not deemed altogether safe to rely upon either of them, consequently in order to be prepared in case of an emergency, the matter was laid before two professional gentlemen who were each occupying chairs in one of the medical colleges of Philadelphia.

column2: They were known to be true friends of the slave, and had possessed withal some experience in Underground Rail Road matters. Either of these professors was willing to undertake the operation, provided arrangements could be completed in time to be carried out during the vacation.
column3: They were known to be true friends of the slave, and had possessed withal some experience in Underground Rail Road matters. Either of these professors was willing to undertake the operation, provided arrangements could be completed in time to be carried out during the vacation.

column2: In this hopeful, although painfully indefinite position the matter remained for more than a year; but the correspondence and anxiety increased, and with them disappointments and difficulties multiplied.
column3: In this hopeful, although painfully indefinite position the matter remained for more than a year; but the correspondence and anxiety increased, and with them disappointments and difficulties multiplied.

column2: The hope of Freedom, however, buoyed up the heart of the young slave girl during the long months of anxious waiting and daily expectation for the hour of deliverance to come.
column3: The hope of Freedom, however, buoyed up the heart of the young slave girl during the long months of anxious waiting and daily expectation for the hour of deliverance to come.

column2: Equally true and faithful also did Mr. Bigelow prove to the last; but at times he had some painfully dark seasons to encounter, as may be seen from the subjoined letter:
column3: Equally true and faithful also did mr Bigelow prove to the last; but at times he had some painfully dark seasons to encounter, as may be seen from the subjoined letter:

column2: WASHINGTON, D.C., October 6th, 1855.
column3: WASHINGTON, d c, october sixth eighteen fifty five.

column2: MR.
column3: mr

column2: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I regret exceedingly to learn by your favor of 4th instant, that all things are not ready.
column3: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I regret exceedingly to learn by your favor of fourth instant, that all things are not ready.

column2: Although I cannot speak of any immediate and positive danger.
column3: Although I cannot speak of any immediate and positive danger.

column2: [_Yet it is well known that the city is full of incendiaries_.]
column3: [underscore Yet it is well known that the city is full of incendiaries underscore.]

column2: Perhaps you are aware that any colored citizen is liable at any hour of day or night without any show of authority to have his house ransacked by constables, and if others do it and commit the most outrageous depredations none but white witnesses can convict them.
column3: Perhaps you are aware that any colored citizen is liable at any hour of day or night without any show of authority to have his house ransacked by constables, and if others do it and commit the most outrageous depredations none but white witnesses can convict them.

column2: Such outrages are always common here, and no kind of property exposed to colored protection only, can be considered safe.
column3: Such outrages are always common here, and no kind of property exposed to colored protection only, can be considered safe.

column2: [I don't say that _much liberty_ should not be given to constables on account of numerous runaways, but it don't always work for good.] Before advertising they go round and offer rewards to sharp colored men of perhaps _one or two hundred dollars_, to betray runaways, and having discovered their hiding-place, seize them and then cheat their informers out of the money.
column3: [I don't say that underscore much liberty underscore should not be given to constables on account of numerous runaways, but it don't always work for good.] Before advertising they go round and offer rewards to sharp colored men of perhaps underscore one or two hundred dollars underscore, to betray runaways, and having discovered their hiding place, seize them and then cheat their informers out of the money.

column2: [_Although a law-abiding man_,] I am anxious in this case of _innocence_ to raise no conflict or suspicion.
column3: [underscore Although a law abiding man underscore,] I am anxious in this case of underscore innocence underscore to raise no conflict or suspicion.

column2: [_Be sure that the manumission is full and legal_.] And as I am _powerless_ without your aid, _I pray you_ don't lose a moment in giving me relief.
column3: [underscore Be sure that the manumission is full and legal underscore.] And as I am underscore powerless underscore without your aid, underscore I pray you underscore don't lose a moment in giving me relief.

column2: The idea of waiting yet for weeks seems dreadful; do reduce it to days if possible, and give me notice of the _earliest possible time_.
column3: The idea of waiting yet for weeks seems dreadful; do reduce it to days if possible, and give me notice of the underscore earliest possible time underscore.

column2: The property is not yet advertised, but will be, [and if we delay too long, may be sold and lost.]
column3: The property is not yet advertised, but will be, [and if we delay too long, may be sold and lost.]

column2: It was a great misunderstanding, though not your fault, that so much delay would be necessary.
column3: It was a great misunderstanding, though not your fault, that so much delay would be necessary.

column2: [I repeat again that I must have the thing done legally, therefore, please get a good lawyer to draw up the deed of manumission.]
column3: [I repeat again that I must have the thing done legally, therefore, please get a good lawyer to draw up the deed of manumission.]
